key_facts: Northern India is experiencing unusually high early-year temperatures.
Forecasts predict temperatures above 40°C in several states, including Delhi.
The Indian Meteorological Department has issued a yellow alert.
The heat poses health risks to vulnerable populations.
Climate experts link intense heatwaves to climate change.
Spring is rapidly disappearing from the seasonal cycle in India.
Uttar Pradesh and Odisha could face up to 11 heatwave days.
These heatwave days exceed historical norms.
India has recorded extreme heat in recent years.
A record high of 50.5°C has been recorded in India.
Thousands of suspected heatstroke cases have been reported.
Authorities are advising the public to take precautions.
Climate patterns suggest heatwave frequency will rise.
Climate patterns suggest heatwave severity will increase.
